id="bix2gndva">Integrated Circuits Can Be Easy to Understand with the Right Teachers</h1>        <div class="entry-meta">            <a href="https://hackaday.com/2019/05/20/integrated-circuits-can-be-easy-to-understand-with-the-right-teachers/#comments" class="comments-counts"><span class="icon-hackaday icon-hackaday-comment" style="background: rgb(0, 0, 0);"></span>                2 Comments            </a>            <ul class="meta-authors vcard author">                <li class="">by:</li>                <span class="fn"><a href="https://hackaday.com/author/mikehackaday/" title="Posts by Mike Szczys" class="author url fn" rel="author" id="oycu65d42">Mike Szczys</a></span>            </ul>        </div><!-- .entry-meta -->        <div class="entry-meta entry-meta-last">            <span class="entry-date published updated" itemprop="datePublished" content="May 20, 2019"><a href="https://hackaday.com/2019/05/20/" title="May 20, 2019 - 1:00 pm" class="" id="74rpgwfyz">May 20, 2019</a></span>            <ul class="share-post">                <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fhackaday.com%2F2019%2F05%2F20%2Fintegrated-circuits-can-be-easy-to-understand-with-the-right-teachers%2F" target="_blank" class=""><span class="icon-hackaday icon-hackaday-facebook" style="background: rgb(0, 0, 0);"></span></a></li>                <li><a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Integrated+Circuits+Can+Be+Easy+to+Understand+with+the+Right+Teachers via @hackaday&url=https%3A%2F%2Fhackaday.com%2F2019%2F05%2F20%2Fintegrated-circuits-can-be-easy-to-understand-with-the-right-teachers%2F" target="_blank" class=""><span class="icon-hackaday icon-hackaday-twitter" style="background: rgb(0, 0, 0);"></span></a></li>                <li><a href="https://plus.google.com/share?url=https%3A%2F%2Fhackaday.com%2F2019%2F05%2F20%2Fintegrated-circuits-can-be-easy-to-understand-with-the-right-teachers%2F&h1=en-US" target="_blank" class=""><span class="icon-hackaday icon-hackaday-google" style="background: rgb(0, 0, 0);"></span></a></li>            </ul>        </div><!-- .entry-meta -->        <div class="entry-featured-image"><img style="height: 449.438px; width: 799px; background: #000"></div>    </header><!-- .entry-header -->    <div class="entry-content" itemprop="articleBody">        <p>For years I’ve been trying to wrap my mind around how silicon chips actually work. How does a purposefully contaminated shard of glass wield control over electrons? Every once in a while, someone comes up with a learning aid that makes these abstract concepts really easy to understand, and this was the case with one of the booths at Maker Faire Bay Area. In addition to the insight it gave me (and hundreds of Faire-goers), here is an example of the best of what Maker Faire stands for. You’ll find a video of their presentation embedded below, along with closeup images of the props used at the booth.</p><p>The <em>Uncovering the Silicon</em> booth had a banner and a tablecloth, but was otherwise so unassuming that many people I spoke with missed it. <a href="https://twitter.com/oskay" target="_blank">Windell Oskay</a>, <a href="https://twitter.com/1lenore" target="_blank">Lenore Edman</a>, <a href="https://twitter.com/tubetimeus" target="_blank">Eric Schlepfer</a>, <a href="https://twitter.com/johndmcmaster" target="_blank">John McMaster</a>, and <a href="https://twitter.com/kenshirriff" target="_blank">Ken Shirriff</a> took a 50-year-old logic chip and laid it bare for anyone who cared to stop and ask what was on display. The Fairchild μL914 is a dual NOR gate, and it’s age matters because the silicon is not just simple, it’s enormous by today’s standards making it relatively easy to peer inside with tools available to the individual hacker.</p><figure id="attachment_359440" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-359440" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="https://hackaday.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/maker-faire-ATmega328-decapped.jpg" target="_blank"><img style="height: 532.328px; width: 799px; background: #000"></a><figcaption id="caption-attachment-359440" class="wp-caption-text">ATmega328 decapped by John McMaster was also on display at this booth</figcaption></figure><p>The first challenge is just getting to the die itself. This is John McMaster’s specialty, and you’re likely familiar from his <a href="http://www.siliconpr0n.org/" target="_blank">Silicon Pr0n</a> website. He decapped the chip (as well as an ATmega328 which was running the Arduino blink sketch with it’s silicon exposed). Visitors to the booth could look through the microscope and see the circuit for themselves. But looking doesn’t mean understanding, and that’s where this exhibit shines.</p><div data-carousel-extra="{"blog_id":1,"permalink":"https:\/\/hackaday.com\/2019\/05\/20\/integrated-circuits-can-be-easy-to-understand-with-the-right-teachers\/"}" id="gallery-1" class="gallery galleryid-359435 gallery-columns-2 gallery-size-medium"><figure class="gallery-item">			<div class="gallery-icon landscape">				<a href="https://hackaday.com/2019/05/20/integrated-circuits-can-be-easy-to-understand-with-the-right-teachers/ul914-transistor-model-square/"><img style="height: 399.5px; width: 399.5px; background: #000"></a>			</div></figure><figure class="gallery-item">			<div class="gallery-icon landscape">				<a href="https://hackaday.com/2019/05/20/integrated-circuits-can-be-easy-to-understand-with-the-right-teachers/ul941-model-legend/"><img style="height: 399.5px; width: 399.5px; background: #000"></a>			</div></figure>		</div><p>To walk us through how this chip works, a stack-up of laser-cut acrylic demonstrates the base, emitter, and collector of a single transistor. The color coding and shape of this small model makes it easy to pick out the six transistors of the 941 on a full model of the chip. This lets you begin to trace out the function of the circuit.</p><p><a href="https://hackaday.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/ul941-model-without-metal-layer.jpg" target="_blank"><img style="height: 400px; width: 400px; background: #000"></a>For me, a real ah-ha moment was the resistors in the design. A resistive layer is produced by doping the semiconductor with impurities, making it conduct more poorly. But how do you zero-in on the desired resistance for each part? It’s not by changing the doping, that remains the same. The trick is to make the resistor itself take up a larger footprint. More physical space for the electrons to travel means a lower resistance, and in the model you can see a nice fat resistor in the lower right. The proof for these models was the final showpiece of the exhibit as the artwork of the silicon die was laid out as a circuit board with discrete transistors used to recreate the functionality of the original chip.</p><p>Windell takes us through the booth presentation in the video below. I think you’ll be impressed by the breakdown of these concepts and how well they aid in understanding. This was a brilliant concept for an exhibit; it brought together interdisciplinary experts whom I respect and whose work I follow, and sought to invite everyone to gain a better understanding of the secrets hiding in the chips that underpin this technological age. This is exactly the kind of thing I love to see at a Maker Faire.</p><p><span id="more-359435"></span></p><p><span class="embed-youtube" style="text-align:center; display: block;"><iframe style="height: 449.438px; width: 799px; background: #000"></iframe></span></p>            </div><!-- .entry-content -->    <ul class="sharing" style="">    					<li class="">    				<a
